review.title: CONDITOR1: Topic Maps and DITA labelling tool for textual documents with historical information
review.abstract: Conditor is a software tool which works with textual documents containing historical information. The purpose of this work two-fold: firstly to show the validity of the developed engine to correctly identify and label the entities of the universe of discourse with a labelled-combined XTM-DITA model. Secondly to explain the improvements achieved in the information retrieval process thanks to the use of a object-oriented database (JPOX) as well as its integration into the Lucene-type database search process to not only accomplish more accurate searches, but to also help the future development of a recommender system. We finish with a brief demo in a 3D-graph of the results of the aforementioned search.

sections.heading: 2 Topic Maps-DITA Approach
sections.text: The project in which this work is framed began as the development of an end-user recommendation system for the online product GEA (Gran Enciclopedia Aragonesa), which helps the user retrieve information. Originally, the goal actually became a specialized processing tool for information on cultural heritage. The information provided by the online encyclopedians does not provide the minimum semantic labeling (see Figure 1) required for the development of the end-user tool. The lack of a semantic one, for example, is obvious and the language field < Description > needs to be analyzed more deeply because there is a lot of important information that depends on the context, such as events, dates, people, marriages, descendants, etc. Previously, a reprocessing of the above information had to be carried out.

sections.heading: 3.1 Introduction
sections.text: The main goal of the conditioner program is to read the XML source (see Figure 1), which in our case is an XML file format; to create entities that represent each of the source structure elements (objects) during this reading phase; to create an XML object with a different structure from these entities (see Figure 3); and finally to allow them to be stored in any system. Of course, this multifactor goal makes us think of numerous technologies that provide for automatic conversion of objects in this format, as well as automatic generation of objects in it. However, the problem that needs to be solved includes the possibility that the XML document reflects a semantic structure that performs such conversion of objects.
